She looks forward to opening her own beauty salon in the future, where she will also be selling beauty products and cosmetics.

loans.use: to acquire new beauty tools and supplies.

loans.name: Zahraa

texts.en:
Zahraa is a 29-year-old married Lebanese woman. She lives with her husband and their two children who are still studying. Her husband is responsible for managing their family’s affairs and covering their daily needs. Her husband owns a grocery shop in his town.

With the requested loan from Kiva partner, Vitas s.a.l, she would like to pay her children’s educational fees. One of her greatest dreams is to save enough money to provide her children with anything that they need.

loans.use: to pay her children’s educational fees

loans.name: Carmen Monserrate

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Grupo De Crédito Mujeres Por EL Progreso.
En este lugar vive la señora Carmen, tiene 57 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos mayores de edad y comprometidos, uno de sus hijos aun viven en su casa con su familia. Su esposo es obrero.
Doña Carmen es una mujer que siempre le hay gustado colaborar con los gastos que genera su hogar ya que a su marido se le hace muy difícil solventarlos ya que no gana mucho en su labor y es por eso que ella desde hace mas de 12 años atrás se dedica al comercio, ella con la ayuda de los crédito empezó vendiendo ropa de todo tipo, luego también empezó a vender productos de Avon, Yanbal, Belcorp(productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas), lo cual le ha ayudado a mejorar sus ganancias,  ellas sale a vender casi todo los días, deja a crédito y cobra cada 8  o 15 días, le encanta vende ya que así se gana la vida y se entretiene.
Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar camisas, pantalones, perfumes y todo  de los que ella vende. Está desde el inicio en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta por los servicios que les ofrece la institución. Sus sueños es seguir mejorando su vida.
texts.en:
The city of Los Bajos de Montecristi is known for its great variety of products, such as the toquilla-straw hats, famous locally and abroad. This is where the "Mujeres por el Progreso" communal bank meets every fifteen days.

This is where Carmen lives. She is 57 years old, and married. She has three adult children who are engaged. One of them, and his family, still live with her. Her husband works as a construction worker.

Carmen is a woman who has always liked to contribute to the sustenance of her home. It is difficult for her husband to do it alone, since he does not earn much. This is why, twelve years ago, she decided to start selling things. She has applied for loans that have helped her to sell all kinds of clothes. Then she started to sell Avon, Yanbal, and Belcorp products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes, accessories for women), which has helped her to improve her profits.

She sells her products almost every day. She sells on credit, and collects the money every week or every two weeks. She loves her job, because that is how she makes a living and keeps herself entertained.

She will use this loan to buy shirts, pants, perfumes, and all the products she sells. She has been a member of this groups since its beginnings. She likes to be one because of the services offered by the institution. Her dream is to continue improving her life.

loans.use: to buy shirts, pants, perfumes, etc.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 27 year old Lebanese single man living with his parents and two siblings. His father is the main income source in his family and he is doing well so far.

As for Mohamad, he works as an employee in a company. Today, he is applying for a loan from Kiva partner, Vitas s.a.l., to pay his sister's educational fees. He states that this loan will help him to ensure a good education for his sister and his school year.

loans.use: to pay his sister's educational fees

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is a hardworking 46-year-old married man with six children. He lives in Kamwenge, Uganda. Three of his children attend school, and he also cares for two other dependents living in his home because they are his parents.

His main source of income is farming, though he also earns income from serving as a builder since 2007. In the future, he wants to have more gardens of coffee, and he is focused on and determined to achieve his dream despite being limited by bad weather.

He requests a loan to buy mulch, manure and fertilizers for his coffee plantation.

loans.use: to buy mulch, manure and fertilizers for his coffee plantation.

loans.name: Sylevano

texts.en:
Sylevano is a 60-year-old married man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He owns a restaurant and a produce business, which he has been running for 30 years now. He started them with the hope of increasing his family income and improving his standard of living.

In future, he is looking at creating a cattle farm and buying more land where he can graze those animals. He has asked for a loan facility to enable him to buy foodstuffs, like bananas, beans, cooking oil, and cabbages among others, to prepare in his restaurant business.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs, like bananas, beans, cooking oil, and cabbages among others, to prepare in his restaurant business.

loans.name: Ndue

texts.en:
Ndue currently has no teeth in his mouth and it has made it difficult for him to eat or speak properly. "I must replace the teeth but find some cheaper alternatives and one of them is having dentures, a dentist told me. This is why I apply for this loan," said Ndue during the interview.

Ndue has been practicing agriculture/livestock for all these past nineteen years. He has two dairy cows and a calf and also a sow with two little female piglets at the moment.

In the land that he owns, he plants feed for the animals, such as fodder and corn, and also has grapevines and other orchards. Ndue sells raw milk, calves, piglets, and fruits, and sometimes eggs and homemade alcohol drink made of grapes called 'raki'.

At times Ndue goes fishing in a lagoon not far from his home, whenever he catches fish more then his family needs, he sells the rest.

loans.use: to have some sort of cheap replacements for the teeth he has had pulled out; he needs dentures.

loans.name: Samia

texts.en:
Samia is a very vigilant, good manager; she manages her household and tailoring business simultaneously. She is 39 years old, married, and a mother with one child. She lives with her husband in Rawalpindi, Pakistan.

She manages her business alone and with the proper procedures. She benefits from her business, but she is now falling short of the savings she had in her account. Now, she is not able to buy the required inventory, such as fabric, threads, ribbons, and several other little items, for her business. Thus, Samia applied for a loan and is thankful for both the Kiva and BRAC Pakistan teams.

loans.use: to invest in her stitching business.

loans.name: Imtiaz

texts.en:
Imtiaz is 59 years of age and is the mother of five children. She lives with her spouse and children in the area of Rawalpindi, Pakistan.

She is a tailor by profession and runs a cloth sewing business to earn an income. She started her cloth sewing business 30 years ago because she wanted to help her husband support the family and meet the household expenses. Nowadays she wants to increase her business.

Imtiaz is requesting a loan amount 50,000 PKR from Kiva’s partner BRAC Pakistan. The loan will be used to buy a sewing machine, which she needs to be able to fulfill the needs of her family and customers on time.

Imtiaz is obliged toward Kiva and its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine for her business.

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en:
Abdallah is a 54-year-old Palestinian refugee and a married father of three children, who has been working as a dentist, providing dental services in a Palestinian refugee camp since 2000. He has 18 years of experience in his business. Abdallah is his family's sole breadwinner.

His business income isn't sufficient to develop his business since it's location in a refugee camp prevents him from setting expensive prices for his dental services, which limits his ability to develop his business.

Abdallah is requesting a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, to buy a dental machine necessary to provide his patients with all requested dental services.

loans.use: to buy a dental machine necessary to provide his patients with all requested dental services.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a Babban Gona maize farmer. With Babban Gona’s support, Halima is thankful that the days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, she has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8 metric tons of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Halima would have had to sell her maize for low prices at harvest to meet her immediate cash needs, such as cash to purchase food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Halima will store the maize she harvests and delay its sale until later in the season when she can obtain a significantly higher price (a premium of up to 37% relative to the harvest price).

With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Halima now has the opportunity to realize her dream of growing her agriculture business for herself and family members. She would like to use this additional income to ensure that all her children get a post-secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating the pressure to sell her maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Sabah

texts.en: Sabah is a 58-year-old Lebanese woman. She is married and lives with her husband and three school-aged children. She works hard to show her determination to improve her family’s way of living. She created her own job by opening a bakery in her house where she has been producing delicious bread since 2009. Today, she is requesting a loan from Vitas s.a.l., a Kiva partner, to increase her inventory of baking products, such as flour and oil. She states that the loan will positively help her extend her job and increase her income by a large percentage. In the future, she plans to borrow more capital from Kiva to further develop her work.

loans.use: to increase her inventory of baking goods, such as flour and oil.

loans.name: Danladi

texts.en:
Danladi is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Danladi has the opportunity to attain yields of up to eight metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Danladi would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing.

Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Danladi can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Danladi will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000 per hectare of land.

Danladi is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Ezekiel Danjuma

texts.en:
Ezekiel is a maize farmer from Gayya village. As a Babban Gona member, Ezekiel is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields (up to 8 metric tons of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer).

Before joining Babban Gona, Ezekiel would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at its lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs, such as cash to purchase food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member, Ezekiel can store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until later in the season, when he can obtain the best price for his maize (a premium of up to 37% relative to the market price at harvest).

Thanks to support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Ezekiel no longer feels pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Ezekiel hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to ensure that all his children get a post-secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating the pressure to sell his maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Bashir

texts.en:
Bashir is a maize farmer from Fulani Gimba village. As a member of Babban Gona, Bashir is excited about the opportunity to become a better farmer. With Babban Gona’s support, he has the chance to attain yields of up to 8 metric tons of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the average yield in Nigeria.

Before joining Babban Gona, Bashir would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs, such as cash to purchase food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Bashir can store his maize and sell it in the future for a price that is up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Bashir is grateful to be part of the Babban Gona family and, in the end, hopes to use his increased earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating the pressure to sell his maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Marguerite

texts.en:
Marguerite is a 33-year-old married woman from Lebanon living with her husband. Her husband is the main income source in the family and works very hard to always be able to fulfill the family's needs to live in a good lifestyle.

She is focusing only on her university. Today, in order to pay her university fees and continue her work on her master's degree, she is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. She said that her target is to achieve a higher position and be able to support her husband financially.

loans.use: to pay her university fees and continue work on her master's degree.

loans.name: Ana Monserrate

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Grupo De Crédito Mujeres Por EL Progreso.
En este lugar vive la señora María, tiene 48 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen cuatro hijos mayores de edad y aun viven en su casa. Su esposo trabaja para el Estado.
Doña Ana es una mujer que siempre le ha gustado ganarse la vida gracias a su labor, ella gracias  a los créditos que recibió del grupo hace mas de 7 años atrás decidió invertir en un negocio el cual mantiene hasta la actualidad y que ha mejorado gracias  a los créditos que siempre recibe del grupo, ella vende ropa de todo tipo,  zapatos y bisuterías entre otras cosas,  su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta, ella sale cada vez que puede y también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes cuando necesitan de alguna prenda, les da facilidades en los pagos y esto les gusta a su clientes por eso la prefieren.
Este crédito es para comprar ropa, zapatos, bisutería entre otras cosas. Está en el Grupo De Crédito desde hace  más de 11 años y está muy agradecida ya que siempre los créditos le ayudan mucho. Sus sueños son seguir contando con la ayuda de los créditos.
texts.en:
Los Bajos de Montecristi is a city that is known for its great diversity in traditional products, such as the straw hats that are known inside and out of the country. This is where the Mujeres Por El Progreso (Women for Progress) communal bank meets every 15 days. 

This is also where Ana lives. She is 48 years old, married and has 4 adult children who still live with her. Her husband works for the government. 

Ana has always liked to earn a living through her work. Thanks to the loans she received from the communal bank 7 years ago, she invested in a business that she still currently has. The business has also improved thanks to the loans she has received. She sells all types of clothing, shoes and custom jewelry, among other items. She sells her products door-to-door every time she has a chance and also at home, where her customers arrive whenever they need a clothing item. She sells on credit, which her customers like and that is why they prefer to buy from her. 

The purpose of this loan is to buy clothes, shoes and custom jewelry, among other items. She has belonged to the communal bank for 11 years and is very thankful as the loans she has received have been very helpful. Her dream is to continue receiving loans in the future.

loans.use: to buy clothes, shoes, costume jewelry, etc.

loans.name: Fadia

texts.en:
Twenty years ago, Fadia was left alone, responsible for raising two children after her beloved husband passed away. She had no income to cover their living needs.

That's why she decided to start a mouneh business from her house. This kind of business helped her take care of her family, and provide them with a good income to cover their living needs.

Today, Fadia, a 53-year-old widowed mother of two, a Palestinian refugee, specializes in the mouneh business. Thus her acquired loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua, will be invested in buying pepper, olives, and chili to prepare her requested mouneh orders which will provide her with a good income.

This is Fadia's first loan from Al Majmoua. She hopes that through the future loans she can expand her business and diversify her production.

loans.use: to buy requested pepper, olives, and chili to prepare her requested mouneh (preserved food) orders which will provide her with a good income.

loans.name: Elgun

texts.en:
Elgun is a single man living with his family in Fuzuli region. His old parents don’t work. Elgun is 23 years old and he is a butcher, which is a family business. He lives in the Bala Bahmanli village of the Fuzuli region with his family. They are IDP (Internally Displaced Persons) from their native land, Fuzuli city.

Elgun has been in this business for three years. In the future, he wants to increase his business. And also he wants to get married.

He has applied to Komak company. Today he needs his first loan in the amount of 2000 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat). With this loan he wants to buy two cows. He is thankful to the Kiva organization and lenders for help.

loans.use: to buy two cows

loans.name: Bahrom

texts.en:
Bahrom was born in 1981 year. He is married and has 2 children. He lives together with his family in a village of Tajikistan. He is very hardworking and kind man. He wants to give a higher education to his children. Bahrom’s elder son is a student of the first course Medical University of Tajikistan.

Bahrom must pay for the university tuition of his son, but his income from his farming business is not enough. Bahrom is asking for a loan to pay for the university tuition. He awaits your support.

loans.use: to pay for his son's tuition at the Medical University

loans.name: Yakubu Aikau

texts.en:
Yakubu is a maize farmer from Gayya village. As a Babban Gona member, Yakubu is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Yakubu would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at its lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member, Yakubu can store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a period later on in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Yakubu no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Yakubu hopes to realize better yields. He plans on using his additional income to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Tamin Ibrahim

texts.en:
Tamin is in his final year at the Methodist University College, reading Banking and Finance. The loan is to enable him pay his tuition fees. He believes education is the only key to opening many job opportunities in life, thus keeping him focused and never giving up in life.

Pursuing his education, he would be able to acquire more knowledge and become a professional banker. He would also be able to increase his income, to help him support his family and community. He wishes to become a senior financial consultant in the future, and he cannot see himself doing that without education.

Denial of this loan facility would have meant that he would have had to defer his studies or plead with school authorities to allow him some time to pay his fees, a move which is not so reliable. He says, “People are so much willing to further their education and be responsible adults, but lack funding, so I am extremely grateful for your support, keep it up.”

loans.use: to pay his tuition fees and hostel fees.

loans.name: Nuhu

texts.en:
Nuhu is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Nuhu has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Nuhu would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Nuhu can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Nuhu will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. Nuhu is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family. He looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Sedrak

texts.en:
Sedrak is 56 years old and he lives in Ddmashen village of Gegharkunik region. Sedrak has higher pedagogical education; he graduated the faculty of mathematics and started 1981 till today he works of his profession. At first he was a teacher of mathematics now he is also the director of the school where he did his first pedagogical steps. He is greatly respected person who does his work properly, works with discipline and considers his work very serious and as an answer the whole school likes him very much. Sedrak is married and his wife is also a pedagogue. They have a son (he is a policeman) and also a daughter (she is already married).

This loan of 1.400.000 Armenian drams Sedrak asks as he has some health problems, which greatly impacts on his activeness and he does not manage to work as properly as he used to and this loan amount will help him to pass course of treatment.

loans.use: to pass course of treatment as he has some health problems, which greatly impacts on his activeness

loans.name: Edik

texts.en:
Edik is 54 years old and he lives with his wife and daughter in Sevkar village in the Syunik region. Edik is engaged in farming and agriculture and at the same time he works as a forester. Edik’s daughter is a student and she studies at the medical college in the department of nursing.

Edik is upset and worried since very suddenly his daughter started to have some health problems. She needs to have an urgent medical examination and Edik and his wife are so hopeful that there will be nothing very serious. This loan of 200.000 Armenian drams that Edik is asking for, will be used to solve his pretty daughter’s health problems.

loans.use: to solve his pretty daughter’s health problems

loans.name: Nuhu

texts.en:
Nuhu is a maize farmer from Makwala village. As a Babban Gona member, Nuhu is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 Metric Tonnes of Maize per Hectare of Land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer. 

Before joining Babban Gona, Nuhu would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member Nuhu can to store the maize he harvests and delay it’s sale until a period later on in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Nuhu no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2000 per Hectare of land, Nuhu hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to build a house for his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Umazi

texts.en:
Umazi is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

She has operated a butcher shop business for the past three years, selling goat meat. She faces major challenges of transportation and seasonality in her business.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase goats to slaughter and get meat to sell.

loans.use: to purchase goats to slaughter and get meat to sell.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is maize farmer from Gayya village. As a member of Babban Gona, Samson is excited about the opportunity to become a better farmer. With Babban Gona’s support he has the chance to attain yields of up to 8 Metric Tonnes of Maize per Hectare of land, 5.5 times the average yield in Nigeria.

Before joining Babban Gona, Samson would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Samson can store his maize and sell it in the future for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.
Samson is grateful to be part of the Babban Gona family and in the end hopes to use his increased earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Daniel Stephen

texts.en:
Daniel is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Daniel is thankful that the days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Daniel would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs, such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Daniel will store the maize he harvests and delay it’s sale until a date later in the season when he can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize at a premium up to 37% more than the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Daniel now has the opportunity to actualize his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and family members and would like to use this additional income to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Murubya School

texts.en:
Greetings from Uganda! This is Moses. He is the Director of Murubya Primary School, a mixed school in the Rural area of Hoima with 700 students. Murubya School has requested a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a UV water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students. The school does not currently have access to consistent clean drinking water and therefore has to spend a considerable portion of its budget on firewood, which is used to boil water for the children. Installing a water filtration system will therefore save the school money in the long-term as the cost of firewood will be reduced. The loan will enable the school to purchase a UV water treatment system with a 750 litre tank, which will be big enough to store clean drinking water for the students every day. 

Murubya School will repay their loan from their school fees, which they collect each term. Moses ultimately hopes that having access to safe drinking water will improve his student’s concentration and attendance by reducing the number of children that fall sick from water-borne diseases as well as increase the number of students coming to the school.

loans.use: to purchase a water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Langat

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photo is Mary. She is 38 years old, married and has four children. She joined hand in hand eastern Africa in the year 2014 to gain knowledge and skills on savings, enterprise management and financial management.

Mary operates a profitable poultry business thus borrowing from Kiva to add more chicks and buy poultry feeds. This will her income will increase thus be in a position to educate her children to higher levels of education, since there will be a high production from her poultry business.
She is happy and grateful for Kiva and their lenders for the support on her business. She therefore promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy more chicks and poultry feed to boost yield, and thus more profits to meet family needs.

loans.name: Uktamhuja

texts.en:
Uktamhuja is an industrious man from rural area of Tajikistan. He is married and bringing up 2 sons. Uktamhuja is higher educated person. He has graduated Tajikistan State University of Politic and Business. Uktamhuja after graduating university couldn’t find job and that’s why he went to Russia. He was a migrant for some years.

Uktamhuja now has been busy with growing vegetables and feeding cows. He works in this field more than 10 years. Uktamhuja now is ill. He must treat his health but he has no money. Uktamhuja is asking for a loan of 10000 Somoni to buy medicines for treatment. He awaits your compassion.

loans.use: To buy medicines for treatment

loans.name: Roise

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photograph is Roise. She is fifty four years old, married and has five children. She joined hand in hand eastern Africa in the year 2014 and she underwent training on enterprise development and financial management. This has brought a great impact in her life.

She grows maize, beans and potatoes for food and commercial purposes. She is borrowing from hand in hand to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers and quality seeds. This will increase the production thus increased income which will enable her provide for her family basic needs, such as food, shelter, clothing and education to her children.

Roise is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers and quality seeds.

loans.name: Yolanda Virginia

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Banco Comunal Mujeres Por EL Progreso.
En este lugar vive la señora Yolanda, tiene  39 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene dos hijos de 12 y 7 años de edad, ambos estudian en colegio y escuela. Su esposo es chofer y mecánico.
Doña Yolanda es una mujer que le gusta sentirse útil y ayudar a su marido con la dura carga de sacar adelante su hogar, es por eso que realiza el crédito para ayudarlo, el tiene un taller mecánico donde realiza todo tipo de trabajos en automóviles, allí  el también vende aceites, líquidos de frenos, tubos, llantas y otros repuestos que necesita y que vende al mismo tiempo que realiza sus trabajos, el lleva más de 15 años con esta labor razón por lo cual sus clientes siempre le llevan sus coches cuando necesitan de algún arreglo.
Este crédito lo va a emplear para comprar aceite, liquido de frenos y repuestos. Lleva 3 ciclos  en el Grupo de Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos son rápidos y sin tantos requisitos. Sus sueños es darle lo mejor a su familia.
texts.en:
In the lower region of Montecristi, a city known for having a great diversity of traditional products, such as straw hat, well known in and out of the country, the communal bank "Mujeres Por EL Progreso" meet every 15 days.

This is where Yolanda lives. She is 39 years old, is married and from that relationship she has two children, 12 and 7 years old. Both are studying in the school. Her husband is a driver and a mechanic.

Yolanda is a woman who likes to feel useful and she helps her husband with the great responsibility of getting their household ahead. This is the reason she is requesting the loan, to help him. He has a repair shop where he provides all types of auto repairs. He also sells oils, brake fluid, tubes, tires and other spare parts, which he sells along with offering repair services. He has been working on this for over 15 years and for this reason his customers always bring their cars to him when they need any type of repairs.

The loan will be used to purchase oil, brake fluid and spare parts. This is their third loan cycle with the Grupo de Crédito and she likes it because the loans are fast and without too many requirements. Their dream is to provide the best for their family.

loans.use: to purchase oil, brake fluid and spare parts.

loans.name: Ashkhen

texts.en:
Ashkhen ended her first Kiva loan but the need of a second deal with Kiva and Nor Horizon is more than important for her family. She lives in Vanadzor city in the Lori region. She lives here with her husband and smallest son, who work as a furniture maker. Their elder son now lives and works in Yerevan city. As previously, Ashkhen works at the clinic in the Vanadzor State Medical College as a senior nurse.

Ashkhen now needs great support since the problem of her husband’s health turned out to be unsolvable and they found out that he has a very serious disease. Unfortunately, there exist no treatment course for him and all that remains is to oppress and control it with medicine. Ashkhen has no way other than to hope that Kiva lenders will help her again a loan amount of 700.000 Armenian drams, which she will use a little bit to lighten the hard state of her husband’s health through special courses at the hospital.

loans.use: to lighten the hard state of her husband’s health through special courses at the hospital.

loans.name: Abdullahi

texts.en:
Abdullahi is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Abdullahi has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Abdullahi would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support Abdullahi can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Abdullahi will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. Abdullahi is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Hauwa Daniel

texts.en:
Hauwa is a maize farmer from Gayya village. As a Babban Gona member, Hauwa is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give her the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Hauwa would have had to sell her maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at its lowest, to meet her immediate cash needs for necessities such as food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member, she can store her harvested maize and delay its sale until a period later on in the season when she can obtain the best price at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Hauwa no longer feels pressure to sell her maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2000 per hectare of land, she hopes to realize better yields and plans on using her additional income to move into a better home with her family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase merchandise such as purses, perfumes, clothing, etc.

loans.name: Edson

texts.en: Edson is a 42-year-old married man with six children. He lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has a business distilling waragi, the local brew produced in his village. He has been doing this since 2005 to earn an income for his family. He is facing challenges of weather changes, especially the heavy rains that make his business come to a stand still. However, in the future, he is looking at constructing rentals as a way to increase his income. Edson has asked for a loan to enable him to pay for labor that is helping him distill the waragi.

loans.use: to pay for labor that is helping him distill waragi

loans.name: Farzana

texts.en: Farzana is a housewife aged 51 and living in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. She is a very caring woman and has been looking after her five children and husband. Her husband owns a bird shop and he has been in this business for four years now. It has been going well, by bringing better profits home than the previous business, so Farzana's husband decided to invest more into his business for even more progressive earning. For this reason Farzana applied for the loan amount. She thanks Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to invest in her husband's bird shop.

loans.name: Barnabas

texts.en:
Barnabas is a maize farmer from Gayya village. As a Babban Gona member, Barnabas is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Barnabas would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price is at its lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs for necessities such as food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member, he can store the maize and delay its sale until a period later on in the season when he can obtain the best price for his crop at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Barnabas no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2000 per hectare of land, Barnabas hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell his maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Ndungiri Muthingi Water Women Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand in the photo is Hannah; she is twenty nine years old, married, and blessed with four children. She is a member of Ndungiri Muthingi Water Women Group, which joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2013 and has undergone all training modules. Hannah does vegetable and dairy farming, a business she has been doing for the last fifteen years.

Hannah has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase fodder, seeds, and fertilizer so that she can increase her farm produce. She plans to use profits generated from improved sales to cater for her family's basic needs and expand her business.

She is grateful for the Kiva loan and promises to make payment promptly.

loans.use: to purchase fodder, seeds, and fertilizer that will increase her farm produce.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 53-year-old lady, married and blessed with four children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2014 to benefit from enterprise development and financial management trainings.

She is involved in mixed farming, i.e., poultry and vegetables, and is able to keep her business records properly. She is requesting a Kiva loan to buy water pipes for irrigating her vegetables so as to get more yields and hence additional income. This will enable her to provide for her family’s basic needs, e.g., food and clothing as well as good shelter.

Jane is grateful to Kiva and its lenders for the help and support.

loans.use: to buy a water pump for irrigation to get more yields and hence additional income to provide for her family's basic needs, e.g., food, clothing, and good shelter.

loans.name: Andria

texts.en:
Andria is 28 years old. He lives with his parents in Rustavi district. Andria is involved in his own business. He serves local people who need to print on clothes, cups, pens, etc. Andria needs an additional printer to expand his business and he requested a loan.

The startup program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables him to get a loan of 1,100 USD. With the received credit he will purchase an additional printer and serve more people with better quality. He is very motivated and loves his job. Andria awaits your support.

loans.use: to expand his business and purchase an additional printer.

loans.name: Rosa Leopoldina

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Grupo De Crédito Mujeres Por EL Progreso.
En este lugar vive la señora Rosa, tiene 72 años de edad, hace varios años su esposo falleció y quedo viuda pero de esta relación tiene 9 hijos mayores de edad, una hija aun vive con ella.
Doña Rosa es una mujer que le gusta trabajar para así ganarse la vida,  ella tiene una tienda de víveres en su casa, allí vende todo tipo de productos de primera necesidad así como también  legumbres, verduras y frutas, carnes, cosas de bazar y papelería, cada vez va mejorando su tienda y esto mucho mas desde que recibe los créditos que le brinda la institución razón por lo cual ella agradece a las personas que le brindan la oportunidad de sacar adelante su negocio y ganarse la vida.
Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar productos de primera necesidad, legumbres, carnes entre otros productos para abastecer su tienda. Esta desde el inicio en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta por las ayuda que recibe con los créditos. Sus sueños son seguir adelante y gozar de buena salud.
texts.en:
The communal bank Mujeres Por El Progreso meets biweekly in Los Bajos de Montecristi, a town known for its diverse traditional products, such as the nationally and internationally well-known Panama hat.

Rosa is one of the members of this group. She is 72 years old. Her husband passed away several years ago, so she is a widow. She has nine adult children from her marriage, and one of her daughters still lives at home with her.

Rosa is a woman who likes to work in order to make a living. She has a grocery store set up at home, where she sells all types of basic products like grains, fruits, vegetables, and meat, as well as miscellaneous items like office supplies. Her store is improving more and more, especially since she started using Kiva loans. For this reason, she is grateful to all of the people who give her the opportunity to keep her business going and make a living.

She will use this loan to stock up on products for her store. She will buy groceries like meat, vegetables, and other products. She has been with her communal bank from the start, and is very happy with the loans she has been able to access.

Her dreams are to keep going and stay in good health.

loans.use: to buy groceries like meat, vegetables, and other basic items.

loans.name: Garik

texts.en:
Garik is 38 years old and he lives with his wife and two school-aged sons in Vanadzor city in the Lori region.

Garik has a bus and for five years already, he has been transferring people from Vanadzor to different parts of the Lori region. He has a lot of passengers and among them are also a lot of students who are from very far villages and need to reach to Vanadzor for their lessons at the Institutes, Universities, colleges, etc. Garik drives very attentively and as he mentions, every day he takes on a great responsibility to transfer many people carefully and on time. So with a great sense of duty and care, he manages his work every day, from early morning until the end of the day.

With this loan of 500.000 Armenian drams that Garik is asking for, he wants to repair the salon of his bus, making it cleaner and more comfortable for his number of passengers.

loans.use: to repair the salon of his bus, making it cleaner and more comfortable for his passengers.

loans.name: Yahaya

texts.en:
Yahaya is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Yahaya is thankful that the days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Yahaya would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Yahaya will store the maize he harvests and delay it’s sale until a date later in the season, when he can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize at a premium up to 37% more than the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Yahaya now has the opportunity to actualize his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and family members and would like to use this additional income to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Ibrahim Mati

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Ibrahim has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tons of Maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Ibrahim had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing.

Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Ibrahim can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim will benefit from marketing support that could help him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land.

Ibrahim is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family, and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating the pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
The lady in the photo is Salome. She is married and a mother of six children. She underwent the hand-in-hand training, benefited from the savings and resource mobilization training, as well as enterprise development.

She does potato and vegetable farming. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy manure for her farm to increase her yields, hence get more income. She plans to use the income to pay school fees for her children and buy a cow.

Salome is grateful to Kiva and it's lenders, and promises to repay her loan on time.

loans.use: to buy manure to increase yields, hence get more income to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Leátu

texts.en:
Leátu is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Leátu has the opportunity to attain yields of up to eight metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Leátu would have had to sell her maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Leátu can store her maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Leátu will benefit from marketing support that could see her generate earnings of up to $2000 per hectare of land. Leátu is thankful that she now has the opportunity to improve the life of her children and family and looks forward to using her additional earnings to provide employment to members of her community through her farm.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Maryamu

texts.en:
Maryamu is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Maryamu has the opportunity to attain yields of up to eight metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Maryamu would have had to sell her maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Maryamu can store her maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Maryamu will benefit from marketing support that could see her generate earnings of up to $2000 per hectare of land. Maryamu is thankful that she now has the opportunity to improve the life of her children and family and looks forward to using her additional earnings to provide employment to members of her community through her farm.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Wikwatyo S.h.g Group

texts.en:
The person raising his hand is Joseph, a member of Wikwatyo S.H.G. He is fifty six years old, married, and a father of seven. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2015 and has benefited from enterprise and financial management trainings.

He is involved in tailoring activity as his main business and through the trainings he has been able to manage his finances well. He is taking a Kiva loan to purchase a higher quality sewing machine that will consequently increase his production, and hence bring him more income. This will assist him to cater for the family’s needs such as food and medical care, and in paying school fees for his grandchildren.

Joseph is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the support and promises to pay promptly.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine to increase productivity, hence getting more income.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is forty nine years old, married, and blessed with four children. Three of her children are currently attending school. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 to benefit from the trainings, especially enterprise development and financial management.

She practices poultry farming as her main economic activity. She is taking a Kiva loan to buy more chicken to expand her poultry farming business. This will enable her to meet the growing demand for eggs and chicken in her locality. With increased income, she will be in a position to meet family needs such as food and clothing, and also support her children’s education.

Janet is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the support.

loans.use: to buy more chicken and expand her poultry business for increased income to meet family needs, e.g., food, clothing, and education.

loans.name: Ndeye

texts.fr:
NDEYE est âgée de 50 ans, elle mariée et mère 7 enfants dont un garçon. Elle s'active dans l'embouche et parallèlement elle fait du commerce de légumes. Elle se rend prés de sa localité pour acheter le bétail et dans une autre région du pays pour acheter les légumes.
Avec le prêt, elle compte acheter deux moutons à 50 000 FCFA l'unité. Elle va aussi acheter de l'aliment de bétail et supporter les soins de vétérinaires pour un montant total de 50 000 FCFA.Elle revend les moutons à 150 000 FCFA l'unité après élevage. Elle compte aussi acheter des légumes avec le reste de l'argent hebdomadairement pour les revendre dans son village.Le transport des marchandises est à sa charge.
Avec les bénéfices, elle envisage de renforcer son activité d'embouche en achetant d'autres moutons, épargner au niveau du banc villageois mais aussi contribuer aux charges familiales.
texts.en:
NDEYE is 50 years old, married and mother to 6 girls and 1 boy. She rears livestock and also sells vegetables. She buys livestock close to her local town and buys vegetables in another region. 

With the requested loan, she will buy two sheep at 50,000 FCFA each. She will also buy animal feed and pay for veterinary care at a total cost of 50,000 FCFA. After breeding, she re-sells the sheep at 150,000 FCFA each. She will use the remaining money to buy vegetables on a daily basis and sell them on in her village. 

She will take care of product transport costs. With the profit she makes she hopes to grow her livestock rearing business by buying more sheep and making savings at her banc villageois, but also contribute towards her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy 2 sheep and vegetables.

loans.name: Mbayang's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe de 24 membres fait partie du banc villageois  qui a été crée  en mai 2011. Il regroupe des femmes qui habitent le même village qui sont très solidaires et très dynamiques. Elles s’activent dans le commerce et l’embouche.
MBAYANG  debout à droite de la photo et levant la main gauche est l’emprunteuse vedette, elle est âgée de 24 ans. Elle est mariée et  mère deux garçons. Elle s’active dans le commerce de mil, d’arachide et de niébé.
Avec le prêt, elle compte acheter 200 kilogrammes de mil le kilo à 150 FCFA, 100 kilogrammes de niébé  le kilo à 250 FCFA et 65 kilogrammes de d'arachide le kilo à 300 FCFA. Elle s’approvisionne dans un marché prés de sa localité.
Les bénéfices serviront à renforcer son épargne au niveau du banc villageois et aussi satisfaire ces besoins personnels.
texts.en:
This group of 24 members is part of the banc villageois that was formed in May 2011. It groups together very close-knit, active women who all live in the same village. They are involved in retail and rearing livestock. 

MBAYANG, pictured standing on the right-hand side of the photo with her hand up, is the featured borrower. She is 24 years old, married and has two boys. She sells millet, peanuts and black-eyed peas.

With the requested loan, she will buy 200 kilograms of millet at 150 FCFA the kilo, 100 kilograms of black-eyed peas at 250 FCFA the kilo and 65 kilograms of peanuts at 300 FCFA the kilo. She purchases this stock at a market close to her local town.

The profits she makes will go towards increasing her savings at the banc villageois and also towards personal needs.

loans.use: to buy millet, peanuts and black-eyed peas.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman and mother of eight children. She underwent the hand-in-hand training, and benefited from the financial management and enterprise development trainings.

She does dairy and vegetable farming. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and certified seeds. She says that this will increase her yields, hence get more profits. She plans to use the profits to buy a sheep and a roof for her house.

Mary is grateful to Kiva and it's lenders and promises to repay her loan on time.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and certified seeds.

loans.name: Istifanus

texts.en:
Istifanus is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Istifanus is thankful that days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to eight metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Istifanus would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Istifanus will store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a date later in the season when he can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize at a premium, up to 37% more than the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2000 per Hectare of land, Istifanus now has the opportunity to actualize his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and family members and would like to use this additional income to purchase a motorbike to do business with.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Sule Dangote

texts.en:
Sule is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Sule has the opportunity to attain yields of up to eight metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Sule would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support Sule can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Sule will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000 per hectare of land. Sule is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Mirtha Azucena

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Grupo De Crédito Mujeres Por EL Progreso.
En este lugar vive la señora Mirtha, tiene 39 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre  y de esta relación tienen tres hijos, de 10, 6  y 4  años de edad, todos  estudian en escuela. Su esposo es comerciante.
Doña Mirtha es  una mujer que le gusta colaborar con su esposo para salir adelante, ella realiza el crédito para que su marido lo utilice en su labor, él se dedica a la venta de materiales de construcción, tiene un camión en el cual entrega estos materiales en los lugares que sus clientes así lo quieran, el vende  madera, arena, piedras, cemento y otros materiales que son utilizados en el campo de la construcción, el compra en grandes depósitos y luego les entrega o también les fleta el camión si así los clientes lo desean, de esta forma el logra ganarse el sustento para toda su familia.
Este crédito lo va utilizar en comprar madera, arena, piedras, cemento y otros materiales de construcción. Lleva 3 ciclos en el Grupo de Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos son rápidos y de mucha ayuda. Sus sueños son tener un depósito de estos materiales y vender también  en su casa.
texts.en:
The communal bank Mujeres Por El Progreso meets biweekly in Los Bajos de Montecristi, a town known for its diverse traditional products, such as the nationally and internationally renowned Panama hat.

Mirtha belongs to this group. She is 39 years old and is in a common-law marriage. She has three children from this relationship, who are ages ten, six, and four. All of them are in school. Her husband is a salesman.

Mirtha is a woman who likes to work with her husband in order for the family to get ahead. She is requesting this loan so that her husband can use it for his work. He sells construction materials and has a truck to deliver them to to the places his customers request. He sells wood, sand, rocks, cement, and other materials that are used in construction. He buys them from large warehouses and then makes his deliveries or rents the truck to his customers if that is what they prefer. This allows him to make a living and support the whole family.

This loan will be used to buy wood, sand, rocks, cement, and other construction materials. Mirtha has been with her communal bank for three cycles. She likes it because the loans are fast and very helpful. Her dream is to have a warehouse for these materials and to also make sales from home.

loans.use: to buy wood, sand, rocks, cement, and other construction materials.

loans.name: Edson

texts.en:
Edson used his previous loan to buy sugar, soap and paraffin to sell. He lives in Kamwenge, Uganda and still owns a retail shop to get income and cater for his family. He also earns an extra income from bodaboda (motorcycle) transport and coffee growing.

With the proceeds from his shop, he has been able to pay school fees for his children. Edson appreciates Kiva for the support given to him, which has enabled his cash flows to increase. Edson hopes that in the future, he will own a wholesale business; though he faces a challenge of high inflation rates and inadequate capital to meet the high demands.
 
Edson intends to use the loan to buy salt, sugar, and cooking oil to sell.

loans.use: to buy salt, sugar, and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Kitoma Tweimukye Group

texts.en: Florence, a member of Kitoma Tweimukye group, is a 47-year-old married woman with children living in Kyenjojo-Uganda. She earns a living from tea crops through growing and tea trade from other growers. She started small from what her father gave her and went on adding to a higher level, having an experience of more than 20 years. She has been able to look after her children and the family at large. As years pass the land also becomes less fertile, which affects the output and calls for the application of manure. Under the group guarantorship, Florence is requesting the loan to buy manure for the tea plantation.

loans.use: to buy manure for the tea plantation.

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel is a maize farmer from Tafki village. As a Babban Gona member, Gabriel is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric Tons of Maize per hectare of land; 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.
 
Before joining Babban Gona, Gabriel would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member, Gabriel can store the maize he harvests, and delay it’s sale until a period later on in the season, when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Gabriel no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Gabriel hopes to realize better yields, and plans on using his additional income to provide employment to members of his community through his farm.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating the pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
Yusuf is maize farmer from Furana village. As a member of Babban Gona, Yusuf is excited about the opportunity to become a better farmer. With Babban Gona’s support, he has the chance to attain yields of up to 8 metric tons of maize per hectare of land; 5.5 times the average yield in Nigeria.
 
Before joining Babban Gona, Yusuf would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Yusuf can store his maize and sell it in the future for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.
 
Yusuf is grateful to be part of the Babban Gona family, and in the end, hopes to use his increased earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating the pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest .

loans.name: María Elizabeth

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Grupo De Crédito Mujeres Por El Progreso.
En este lugar vive la señora María, tiene 33 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen dos hijos de 11 y 10 años de edad, ambos  estudian en  escuela. Su esposo no tiene trabajo fijo.
Doña María es una mujer que le gusta apoyarle a su marido para sacar adelante su hogar y a sus hijos que son lo más importante para ella, para lograr sus recursos ella hace 7 años  y con ayuda de su primer crédito construyo un pequeño corral en su casa en la cual se dedico a la cría de pollos, con cada crédito que ha seguido recibiendo ha podido ir mejorando su producción y  esto le ha permitido ir mejorando la calidad de vida de ella y sus hijos, es por eso que ella está muy contenta y agradecida con la fundación y con las personas que le ayudan para que ella reciba sus créditos..
Este crédito es para comprar más pollos ya que se viene una buena temporada y espera estar lista para vender a muy buen precio. Lleva más de 7 años en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta por la ayuda que siempre le dan. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Los Bajos de Montecristi is a town renowned for its great variety of local products, such as straw hats made from toquilla palm leaves, famous throughout the country and even abroad. There the members of communal bank Mujeres Por El Progreso ("Women for Progress") meet every other week.
María is 33 years old and lives in this town. She's married and from this marriage she has two children, aged 11 and 10, who are both in school. María's husband doesn't have a permanent job.
María is a woman who likes to support her husband so that she can get her household and her children ahead. Their children are her greatest priority. In order to obtain financial resources, she built a small pen in her house with the help of her first loan 7 years ago. There she raised chickens and with each loan she has received she has been able to improve production. This has allowed her to gradually improve her and her children's living conditions. That's why she's very happy and thankful to the foundation and the people who support her so that she can get her loans.
This loan is to purchase more chickens, since a favorable season is approaching and she hopes to be ready to sell at very good prices. She has been with the community bank for over 7 years and she likes it because of the help they always provide to her. Her dream is to give her children the very best in life.

loans.use: to purchase chickens.

loans.name: Dauda

texts.en:
Dauda is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Dauda is thankful that the days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Dauda would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Dauda will store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a date later in the season when he can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize, at a premium up to 37% more than the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Dauda now has the opportunity to actualize his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and family members. He would like to use this additional income to ensure that all his children get a post-secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell his maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en:
Iliya is a maize farmer from Shawai village. As a member of Babban Gona, Iliya is excited about the opportunity to become a better farmer. With Babban Gona’s support, he has the chance to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the average yield in Nigeria.

Before joining Babban Gona, Iliya would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Iliya can store his maize and sell it in the future for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Iliya is grateful to be part of the Babban Gona family and, in the end, hopes to use his increased earnings to ensure that all his children get a post-secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell his maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Dos De Mayo-Chancamayo Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “DOS DE MAYO-CHANCAMAYO”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Quellouno, perteneciente a la provincia de La Convencion  y departamento de Cusco.

La socia Matilde tiene 32 años, es una persona trabajadora y luchadora su deseo de salir adelante junto con su familia hace que todos los días se dedique a la agricultura.
La socia solicito el préstamo para comprar abono. Ella desea cultivar todo tipo de frutas para poder venderlos.

Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de animales, negocio de agricultura, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de venta de comida.

Los socios están contentos y agradecen los inversionistas de KIVA  por el crédito otorgado, se comprometen a pagar puntualmente su cuotas.
texts.en:
The members belong to the “DOS DE MAYO-CHANCAMAYO” [2nd of May-Chancamayo] communal bank. It is located in the district of Quellouno, which belongs to the province of La Convencion and Cusco department.

The member Matilde is 32 years old and a hard worker and fighter who would like to get ahead together with her family. She makes a living every day through agriculture. The member requested a loan to buy compost. She would like to cultivate all types of fruit to sell. 

The other members work selling animals, an agriculture business, a grocery store and a business selling food. The members are happy and thankful for the loans granted by KIVA investors. They commit to promptly pay their dues.

loans.use: to buy compost.

loans.name: Aliyu

texts.en:
Aliyu is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Aliyu has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tons of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Aliyu would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Aliyu can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Aliyu will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. Aliyu is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family. He looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all of his children get a post-secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Usman

texts.en:
Usman is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Usman has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tons of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Usman would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Usman can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Usman will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. Usman is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family. He looks forward to using his additional earnings to build a house for his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
Yusuf is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Yusuf has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tons of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Yusuf would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Yusuf can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Yusuf will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. Yusuf is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family. He looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all of his children get a post-secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is 41 years old and has five children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2014 to benefit through enterprise and financial management in order to run her farming business well. She does mixed farming of maize, bananas and beans. She is borrowing a Kiva loan  to buy fertilizer and seeds in order to increase her production and hence increase her income.This will improve her living standards since she can now pay school fees for her children. She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds in order to increase her production and hence increase her income.

loans.name: Abubakar

texts.en:
Abubakar is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, he has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Abubakar would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs for necessities such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, he can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Abubakar will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000 per hectare of land. Abubakar is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family, and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Daphney

texts.en:
Daphney (43) lives in Hammanskraal with her four children. She is a single mother who works hard to provide for her children.
She is an experienced entrepreneur, having run a small retail business for many years, and now wants to start a butchery. Daphney is requesting a Kiva loan to buy a scale, deep freezer and braai stand (barbecue grill). She will also buy meat stock. With the profit she will be making she will be able to send her children to a good school.

In future she wants to expand and open more branches so that she creates more jobs.

loans.use: To buy a scale, deep freezer, braai stand and stock

loans.name: Johamy Concepcion

texts.es: Johamy de 39 años de edad vive en casa propia con sus dos hijas desde hace 13 años, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa para dama, caballeros y niños su negocio esta ubicado en el mercado municipal y posee muchos clientes, de esta forma se gana la vida y lleva el sustento a su hogar, la clienta desea invertir en su negocio en la compra de mayor cantidad de mercadería para lo cual solicita este crédito a INTEGRAL para la compra de variedad de ropa como: faldas, pantalones, vestidos, blusas, ropa interior, etc. De esta forma espera mejorar sus ventas y sus ingresos con el fin de mejorar su calidad de vida y la de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Johamy is 39 years old and for the past 13 years has lived in her own home with her two daughters. 

She makes a living by selling clothes for women, men, and children. Her business is located in the city market and she has many customers. This way she earns a living and provides for her family. The client would like to invest in her business by buying merchandise in bulk for which she is requesting a loan from INTEGRAL to buy a variety of clothes such as: skirts, pants, dresses, blouses, undergarments, etc. 

This way she hopes to improve her sales and her income in order to improve her and her kids quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a variety of clothes such as: skirts, pants, dresses, blouses, undergarments, etc.

loans.name: Oyimniso

texts.ru: Ойимнисо молодая женщина в возрасте 32 лет проживающая в сельской местности. Ойимнисо замужем и имеет 1 ребенка. Муж Ойимнисо работает на поле по сезону трактористом. Сын помогает по хозяйству и ухаживает за скотом. Животноводством Ойимнисо начала заниматься после замужества для того, чтобы помочь мужу обеспечивать семью. Муж поддержал жену в начинаниях и помог купить пару голов молодого скота. Постепенно она смогла увеличить поголовье скота и получать хорошую прибыль от их продажи. Благодаря бизнесу Ойимнисо ее семья живет в достатке. На данный момент из за упадка цен на скот Ойимнисо не может продать взрослый скот не потеряв часть прибыли. С данной проблемой она решила обратиться в Арванд за финансовой поддержкой. На полученные деньги она хочет закупить корм для скота на зиму и молодой скот по низкой цене.
texts.en:
